docs.lead_paragraph: Defending himself against a growing ad boycott, Rush Limbaugh told his audience on Monday that the companies that have defected from his radio program have decided ''they don't want you or your business anymore.'' ''So be it,'' he said, reassuring his audience that the advertisers would be replaced.

headline.main: Limbaugh Says 'So Be It' Over Boycott

docs.abstract: Radio host Rush Limbaugh, defending himself against a growing ad boycott, says 'so be it;' despite apologizing for his comments about a Georgetown University law student, several more companies say they will not run ads on his show. Photo (M)5

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite an apology on Saturday, Rush Limbaugh is facing a loss of advertisers unnerved by growing criticism of his comments about a Georgetown University student last week.

headline.seo: Limbaugh Advertisers Flee Show Amid Storm
headline.main: Limbaugh Advertisers Flee Show Amid Storm
headline.print_headline: Limbaugh Advertisers Flee Show Amid Storm

docs.abstract: Rush Limbaugh, despite an apology, faces losing his radio talk show advertisers unnerved by growing criticism of his comments about a Georgetown University student; ad boycott is uncomfortable but not crippling for Limbaugh, who is estimated to make $50 million a year and whose program is a profit center for Premiere Radio Networks, company that syndicates it.
docs.snippet: Despite an apology on Saturday, Rush Limbaugh is facing a loss of advertisers unnerved by growing criticism of his comments about a Georgetown University student last week.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ahead of the church’s annual lobbying day in Albany, Timothy M. Dolan told an audience that Catholics needed to make their voices heard more clearly.

headline.seo: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan Urges Catholics to Become More Politically Active
headline.main: Dolan Urges Catholics to Become More Active in Politics

docs.abstract: New York Cardinal Timothy M Dolan tells Roman Catholics that in an era when the church is fighting the government on several fronts, they need to make their voices heard more clearly in the political sphere; speech comes in advance of the church's annual lobbying day in Albany, NY.
docs.snippet: Ahead of the church’s annual lobbying day in Albany, Timothy M. Dolan told an audience that Catholics needed to make their voices heard more clearly.
